name: lion
additionalClues: This animal's social structure is unique among big cats.
The males of this species have a mane that grows darker as they age.
This animal's roar can be heard from as far as 5 miles away.
Some populations of this animal are known to climb trees.

name: tiger
additionalClues: This animal has the largest canine teeth of any big cat, which can reach up to 4 inches in length.
Unlike most other big cats, this species is a strong swimmer and enjoys being in water.
The stripes on this animal's coat are unique to each individual, much like human fingerprints.
This animal's fur color can vary, with white and golden variations occurring in the wild.

name: elephant
additionalClues: This animal has a highly developed brain and exhibits complex problem-solving abilities.
The pregnancy of this animal lasts approximately 22 months, which is the longest known gestation period of any land animal.
This animal's tusks are actually elongated incisor teeth that continue to grow throughout its life.
This species communicates using low-frequency sounds that can travel long distances.

name: giraffe
additionalClues: This animal has the same number of neck vertebrae as humans, but each vertebra is much larger.
The long neck of this species helps it to reach high branches for browsing on leaves, and also to spot predators from a distance.
The tongue of this animal can be up to 18 inches long and is blueish-purple in color.
This animal's heart can weigh up to 25 pounds and needs to generate twice the blood pressure of other mammals to pump blood up its long neck.

name: zebra
additionalClues: The black and white stripes on this animal's coat are thought to help deter biting insects.
This animal's stripes may also serve as a form of camouflage, making it difficult for predators to single out individuals from a group.
Despite their appearance, this animal is actually more closely related to the wild ass than the horse.
When threatened, this animal can deliver powerful kicks to defend itself against predators.

name: crocodile
additionalClues: This animal can replace each of its 80 teeth up to 50 times in its lifetime.
This reptile is known for its 'death roll,' a spinning maneuver used to subdue and dismember prey.
This animal's eyes, ears, and nostrils are located on the top of its head, allowing it to remain mostly submerged while stalking prey.
Despite their large size, this species can launch themselves out of the water using their powerful tail.

name: kangaroo
additionalClues: This animal is known for its powerful hind legs and distinctive hopping locomotion.
Females of this species have a pouch in which they carry and nurse their young.
This animal can cover large distances with minimal energy expenditure due to the elastic tendons in their legs.
Males of this species will sometimes engage in 'boxing' matches to establish dominance or compete for mates.

name: polar bear
additionalClues: Its liver contains toxic levels of vitamin A, which can be fatal if consumed by humans.
It has black skin to absorb heat more efficiently from the sun.
Despite being a marine mammal, it is classified under the same family as the brown bear.
Its scientific name, Ursus maritimus, means 'sea bear'.

name: penguin
additionalClues: This animal is primarily found in the Southern Hemisphere, with only one species found near the equator.
This bird is flightless, but it is an excellent swimmer and can reach impressive speeds underwater.
Some species of this animal are known to make long treks across the ice to reach their breeding grounds.
The male of this species incubates the egg while the female goes to find food, sometimes traveling hundreds of miles.

name: dolphin
additionalClues: This creature is hunted for tradition brutally in some parts of the world.
It sleeps with one eye open and half of its brain remains active to maintain vital functions.
They have been observed to engage in cooperative hunting strategies to catch fish.
There are almost 40 different species, and they can be found in both saltwater and freshwater environments.

name: shark
additionalClues: This animal has a unique, cartilaginous skeleton instead of one made of bone.
Some species of this animal can lose and regrow thousands of teeth over their lifetime.
This animal has an incredible sense of smell, being able to detect tiny amounts of blood from miles away.
Some species of this animal can go into a state of tonic immobility when flipped upside down, which is used by researchers to handle them safely.

name: gorilla
additionalClues: It shares approximately 98% of its DNA with humans.
The males are the biggest 'alpha-males' in the entire world
There are two species, the Eastern and the Western, which are further divided into four subspecies.
It is known to use tools in the wild, such as sticks for extracting termites from their mounds.

name: rhinoceros
additionalClues: It has limited turn rate.
There are five species, and three of them are native to Southern Asia.
You could probably outrun it running in a ZigZag direction.
The white species is the largest of the five and can weigh over 2,300 kg (5,000 lbs).

name: hippopotamus
additionalClues: It secretes a red fluid from its skin that acts as a natural sunscreen and antimicrobial.
Despite its size and weight, it can reach speeds of up to 30 km/h (19 mph) on land.
Its closest living relatives are cetaceans, such as whales and dolphins.
The name means 'river horse' in ancient Greek.

name: cheetah
additionalClues: It is the only big cat that cannot fully retract its claws.
They don't roar, they meow.
Its tear marks help to reduce glare and improve its vision during hunts.
It has a highly specialized respiratory system to allow for rapid oxygen intake during sprints.

name: jaguar
additionalClues: It has the strongest bite force relative to its size among big cats.
Unlike other big cats, it often kills its prey by piercing the skull with its powerful jaws.
Its name is derived from a Native American, which means 'he who kills with one leap.'
It is an excellent swimmer and often hunts in the water.

name: koala
additionalClues: It has a specialized digestive system called a 'hindgut fermenter' to break down the eucalyptus leaves it consumes.
Despite its nickname, it is not a bear but a marsupial.
It has a unique vocal organ that allows it to produce low-frequency mating calls.
Its fingerprints are remarkably similar to human fingerprints.

name: panda
additionalClues: It has a modified wrist bone called a 'pseudothumb' that helps it grip bamboo stalks.
Despite being classified as a carnivore (the species is), its diet consists almost entirely of bamboo.
It has a unique reproductive cycle, with a very short window of just a few days each year for successful mating.
Its coloration may help with temperature regulation or camouflage.

name: wolf
additionalClues: It is one of the most adaptable predators, capable of surviving in various environments from Arctic tundra to desert.
Its complex social structure is based on a strict hierarchy within the pack, led by an alpha pair.
It communicates through a combination of vocalizations, body language, and scent marking.
It has been known to travel long distances, up to 200 miles in a day, in search of prey.

name: sloth
additionalClues: Its slow metabolism allows it to survive on a low-energy diet of leaves.
A unique network of blood vessels in its head prevents blood from pooling when it's inverted.
It has a symbiotic relationship with algae that grow on its fur, providing camouflage.
Its long, curved claws are adapted for gripping branches and climbing trees.

name: orangutan
additionalClues: It is the largest arboreal mammal and spends most of its life in trees.
It has a high level of problem-solving intelligence and has been known to use tools in the wild.
Males develop large cheek pads called 'flanges' as they mature, which may be a sign of dominance.
Its name means 'person of the forest' in Malay.

name: chimpanzee
additionalClues: Despite it weighing less than an average adult-sized human, it is about 1.35 times stronger than us.
It has a complex social structure, with communities consisting of multiple smaller groups called 'sub-units'.
It is capable of using tools, such as sticks to extract termites from mounds, and has been observed using medicinal plants.
It communicates through a variety of vocalizations, gestures, and facial expressions.

name: octopus
additionalClues: This animal has three hearts and its blood is blue in color.
Most species of this animal can change their skin color and texture to blend into their surroundings.
This animal is known for its intelligence, including problem-solving and escape artist abilities.
The female of this species often dies after laying eggs, as she spends her remaining energy caring for and protecting them.

name: platypus
additionalClues: This animal is one of the few mammals that lay eggs.
This species has a unique bill that is covered in skin, with a highly sensitive electroreceptive system.
The male of this species has venomous spurs on its hind legs that can deliver a painful sting.
This animal is endemic to eastern Australia and Tasmania, inhabiting freshwater environments.
